name: 3,5-dimethyl-4-iodophenol
Reason: The basic unit for the compound is phenol, which has a melting point of around 41°C. Each methyl group is expected to increase the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. A single methyl group could be estimated to increase the melting point by about 5°C, thus two methyl groups would contribute an increase of around 10°C. The iodine substituent is a large, electron-dense group that will also increase the melting point considerably; an estimate for a halogen such as iodine could be around 40°C due to its significant mass and size. However, the presence of the hydroxyl (-OH) group creates strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding that greatly increases the melting point. Considering a strong -OH influence, this could be estimated to contribute an additional 50°C increase. All combined adjustments need to add up to reflect the known melting point.
Prediction: 41 (base phenol melting point) + 10 (two methyl groups) + 40 (iodine) + 50 (hydroxyl group hydrogen bonding) = 141°C
